title: How many fatalities will result from fighting between the armed forces of Azerbaijan and either the Nagorno-Karabakh Defense Army or the armed forces of Armenia between 20 June 2017 and 1 July 2018?
preds: Found the quote - Fighting has flared again along the line of contact between Azerbaijani and Armenian forces as it appears that Baku is taking advantage of Yerevan’s distraction during and after the Velvet Revolution to make some territorial gains in the decades-long conflict.
According to an BNE news summary there is renewed action in the contested border region.
Looks like about 20 killed at this point, though I have no idea what source GJO will use to resolve this question.
Going all in because I can only find scattered reports of casualties last June and it seems they probably just get over 10 with a couple months to go.
Staying heavy on under 100 while acknowledging potential to go over if Azerbaijan decides to capitalize on Armenian unrest...

I think there is a 95% chance this will end in between 10 and 99 fatalities and a 5% this will end in 100-999. I think this because the conflict is only continuing to escalate, especially in terms of violence, and also territorial disputes are one the most major causes of war.
Constant daily shelling from Armenia, both sides. Probably under under orders not to fire, or respond to avoid de-escalation. Two Armenian soldiers this year. Are Azerbaijanis getting drawn in?
Pushing up the tail a little bit to account for volatility.

The average number of fatalities per year in conflicts between the the armed forces of Azerbaijan and either the Nagorno-Karabakh Defense Army or the armed forces of Armenia has been of the order of 50 of the past 10 years, with the 200+ casualties of the 2016 confrontation contributing a lot to that number. If the current rate of casualties within the question's time-frame (~12 found through various web searches), and the fact that we are 2/3 through the time period, seems to point to about 18 total fatalities before July 1st, barring any changes in the political / skirmish situation. Even if I missed reports of fatalities, the number would still fall into the 10-99 bin (I would have had to have missed 40 casualties since June 30th to push the expected number of total fatalities in the time period to have 1% in the next higher bin). I estimate at 10% the probability that some skirmish over a one-year period would develop into a repeat of 2016. This would mean about 3% chance of that happening over the next 3 months, so I'll nudge the probability of the  100-999 bracket up by that amount.
An Armenian soldier killed: http://en.apa.az/nagorno_karabakh/armenian-soldier-killed-in-nagorno-karabakh-7514.html But the level of violence seems low at this point.

With the exception of 2016, which saw an abnormally high number of casualties in Nagorno-Karabakh (around 220 combat casualties), 2014 and 2015 saw 60 and 90 combat casualties, respectively. Estimates for the entirety of 2017 show about 50 combat deaths, which included 2 deadly attacks in February (not included in the time period for the question). Since June 2017, fighting in the region has been mostly limited to occasional skirmishes and disputes. Although data on all fatalities (not just combat) is not readily available, I would expect that lower levels of fighting between either Armenia or Nagorno-Karabakh and Azerbaijan would result in a reduced number of civilian and third-party casualties as well. The number of fatalities for this time period is already in the 10-99 range and there is a low chance fatalities will exceed 99 in the given time period due to this reduced fighting. For this reason, I think there is an 88% chance that between 20 June 2017 and 1 July 2018 there will be 10-99 fatalities and only a 12% chance for 100-999 fatalities. I think there is a 0% chance for 1,000 or more fatalities because that would require a scale of fighting that would severely interrupt oil and gas exports in the region, which goes against the broader interests Azerbaijan. 
https://www.cfr.org/interactives/global-conflict-tracker?marker=23#!/conflict/nagorno-karabakh-conflict
https://eurasianet.org/s/karabakh-more-relative-calm-ahead-in-2018
http://www.dw.com/en/russia-deploys-nuclear-capable-missile-system-in-kaliningrad-reports/a-42474925?maca=en-RSS_en_Flipboard-9487-xml-media I'm closer to 10 than 99 so not raising yet

Everything recently has been very low casualty conflict, so if that continues, which with the current air of rebellion in different areas seems likely, more tit-for-tat retaliation seems likely, but I don’t think Russia will allow a large scale escalation in it’s sphere of influence.

This is part of bigger picture.
In Nagorno-Karabakh conflict,  Armenia (Nagorno-Karabakh Defense Army) is backed by Russia and Azerbaijan is backed by Turkey. Nothing serious will happen here without Putin's or Erdogan's permission.  It was clearly seen in 2015/2016 when Turkey downed Russian fighter jet over Syria conflict in Nagorno Karabakh escalated and casualties skyrocketed. After 2016 failed coup in Turkey relations between Putin and Erdogan improved significantly. Probably thanks to the fact that Putin warned Erdogan. Why he did it despite recently dawned plane? Putin needed ally in Syria rather then foe as well as he  took opportunity to create disagreement among strong NATO members Turkey and USA. Now Erdogans blames USA for supporting failed coup.  There is also Soccer World cup happening in Russia in June/July 2018. Putin won't let any conflict involving Russia during that time. Probably there will be something significant happening just after World Cup, however I doubt if Nagorno Karabakh will be the scene.  Bottom line: There won't be escalation without Putin's or Erdogan's approval. And as those two are getting closer and closer allies I do not see any chances for many casualties till July 2018.
Could flare up (or not). When it does flare up fatalities usually in dozens.
Winter conditions in the mountains will keep troop movements to a minimum until spring, conflict will resume in the summer, but there is a small chance of a truce.
Shifting a bit lower based on reports of deaths thus far.
WoC swapping 95% of 100-999 to 10-99. (WoC=Wisdom of Crowd)

Mayber 12 deaths since 20 June 2017. Two more soldiers die, but not sure how it happened: http://en.apa.az/nagorno_karabakh/two-armenian-soldiers-die-in-nagorno-karabakh-4117.html Rate of 4 deaths per month for past 3 months. Would equal about 48 for period of question.
Foloowing @praedico on the basis of  base rate calculation
Decreasing, as things have not gotten heated as of late. It could still spark into a larger conflict, but if the trend maintains, it seems likely it'll be below 100 fatalities.

Possibly as many as 22 killed in 2017 so far. So rate of 2.5 per month. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_conflict#2017 Since 20 June, maybe 10 killed.  Ten more months to go. So I am thinking 20-50 more dead. But that is fewer than last year. Putting some in the 100+ bucket, in case there is an "incident".

Armenia 126 times breaks ceasefire with Azerbaijan in 24 hours
Trend News Agency Website. (2017). Armenia 126 times breaks ceasefire with Azerbaijan in 24 hours. Trend. Retrieved from
https://en.trend.az/azerbaijan/karabakh/2792179.html

Another Azeri soldier has been killed (https://en.trend.az/azerbaijan/karabakh/2782181.html). This puts the fatalities at 8-11, depending which news source is reporting. If this trend of ceasefire violations continues, it's likely this will become an over-under on the 100 mark. Open hostilities could always erupt at any time, but no one really wants that at the moment.

Slightly increasing the likelihood of breaking 100 based on recent news reporting (22 June: http://asbarez.com/164497/4-azerbaijani-soldier-killed-after-artsakh-forces-rebuff-attack/, 5 July: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-armenia-azerbaijan-conflict-idUSKBN19Q1VG, 10 July: https://news.am/eng/news/399672.html), which puts the total dead at 7 since June 20. 3 Armenian soldiers were also injured during an Azerbaijani attack on July 7th, but reporting indicates they are still alive and recovering. Still 7 dead and at least 3 wounded in the past month doesn't indicate things will improve.  Additionally, it seems that peace negotiations are failing to make any progress (http://www.panorama.am/en/news/2017/07/15/The-OSCE-Minsk-Group/1808241), which will only increase the likelihood of more frequent cease fire violations and potentially ramping up use of military force between both sides.
This is a really hard one to call. My instinct is that we will see more of the same, but who knows. Armenia has revenge in mind and Azerbaijan has cause to wag the dog.
Adding to the ever increasing risk of this boiling over: http://en.apa.az/nagorno_karabakh/azerbaijan-says-holding-illegal-presidential-election-in-nagorno-karabakh-is-ridiculous.html.
Intervention by EU --> they fear an escalation is sooner than later? http://armenianweekly.com/2017/07/13/members-of-european-parliament-urge-azerbaijan-to-stop-using-human-shields/

Interesting article that gives numerous reasons why the mood in both Armenia and Azerbaijan means an escalation in the conflict might occur in the relatively short term
http://armenianweekly.com/2017/07/11/will-the-caucasus-see-another-war/
If accurate, this puts the number to 3: http://oc-media.org/soldier-killed-in-nagorno-karabakh/.

The fall of the buckets makes this particularly tricky – not that every other element of the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict isn’t already complex.  Initially, I discount the possibility of fewer than 10 fatalities over the period - the latest news points to further deaths this weekend (http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/news/243883/). Historically, talks have been frequently hyped and invariably ineffective in bringing about change in the region. I currently see no meaningful difference in today’s limited efforts, and doubt de-escalation could possibly occur before the fatality toll exceeds the lower bracket.  At the other end of the scale, there is obviously potential for a significant conflict to erupt that could take more than 1000 lives. The parties have refrained from full scale war, not least due to the likelihood of significant casualties and economic consequences for both sides. ICG highlight that the two parties are “closer to war than at any stage since 1994” (https://www.crisisgroup.org/europe-central-asia/caucasus/nagorno-karabakh-azerbaijan/244-nagorno-karabakhs-gathering-war-clouds). The climate – as has been noted by journalists and think tanks, is certainly increasingly strained, but it seems more likely that associated violence would play out as an increasing number of small scale skirmishes rather than a conflict that would claim over 1000 lives. I believe this primarily because neither side benefits from full scale, wide ranging conflict, and nor do the main international actors, including Russia. While it cannot be ruled out entirely that either an ill-judged decision or an unintentional escalation could lead to a conflict protracted enough to kill over 1000 people, it is therefore less likely than the other alternatives. Two other options remain, and while I expect that any casualty toll will fall into these two buckets it is not easy to choose between the two. Ultimately, historical figures suggest that the baseline is under 100 casualties a year. The trend appears to be towards increasing violence (certainly the last 3 years have seen increasingly bad flare-ups), and with early ceasefire breaches and continuing bellicose rhetoric it tilts me to upgrade the possibility that deaths may rise above the historical baseline. If there were to be one or more escalations like last April that nonetheless remained brief and contained that would also strengthen the likelihood of the final toll falling between 100-999. This leads me to strengthen that bucket, despite the lower historical average.

Azerbaijan is the state that holds the most power in the conflict over the Nagorno-Karabakh region.  Thus far, the Armenian contingent within the Azerbaijani borders have acted as the aggressor and the fatality count is low.  The attacks were mortars and, as in most wars, civilians were the majority of the fatalities.  The situation could be compared to the start of a bad year in Israel.  Most sources say the fatality count is now 2.

High likelihood of occasional mortar fire, mines, and sniper fire causing small numbers (10-99) of casualties, but none of the parties involved -- or their proxies -- want to escalate tensions over N-K that could spark a serious regional armed conflict.

new tactic from Armenia to conflagrate? WashingPost. Washington Times today
A near-daily incidence, the Armenian military alternately shells, mortars, snipes at civilians along the “line of contact,” the line of demarcation that separates Azerbaijan proper from its occupied territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. Often used as a harassment and instigation tactic, seemingly geared to draw Azerbaijan into a larger-scale conflagration, the Fourth of July incident is indicative of new Armenian military doctrine — avoidance of the Azerbaijani military in favor of engaging civilian targets — challenging Azerbaijan to respond as an aggressor.

All of the outside forces (Russia, Turkey, Iran, USA, Georgia) would not benefit from a large conflict with thousands killed and they would probably work hard to keep that from happening so 1,000 or more may be unlikely. Smaller incidents are very likely with so many forces so close to each other and more than 100 fatalities have occurred in recent years.
Unfortunately, it appears the casualty count for the period begins (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-40504373).

Peace attempts are in progress, but yielding little results (https://www.azernews.az/karabakh/115622.html). If this conflict does erupt, casualties will likely exceed 100, and if the fighting is prolonged, over 1,00 becomes much more likely. In the 1988-1994 Nagorno-Karabahk War, combined casualties exceeded 27,000 on the lower estimate (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_War). Watch to see how the peace attempt goes for an indication of the volatility of this situation.

As I feared, nobody I know is much help on this, except they think the group consensus here is too conservative.  Tinkering a bit, but people closer to the action often suppose things to be worse than folks more removed.  Sadly, sometimes those closer to the action are right, of course.  Stay tuned.

I normally hate using wikipedia as a primary source but they have the data I need here. 2016 was an usually bloody year with a couple hundred dead. But going back a decade between 10-99 people died each year. Still, the clashes in 2016 suggest both sides might be getting tired of the stalemate. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_conflict
A placeholder until I can research more after some travel.

From the Carnegie Council:
"Time to Reset U.S. Policy in the South Caucasus"
http://carnegieendowment.org/2017/06/13/time-to-reset-u.s.-policy-in-south-caucasus-pub-71256 "First, America’s top priority should be to help prevent the region’s longstanding conflicts, particularly Nagorno-Karabakh, from heating up. A resumption of fighting would have devastating socio-economic and political consequences for all three countries and the broader neighborhood, which includes key US allies around the already tense Black Sea region. Keeping the lid on regional conflict will be a tall order. "

Estimating between 10 - 20 by December, 2017, no where near 400-600+ reported in 2016 A fair bit of economic pressure that could stoke things both internally as GDP contracting, and currency seems free-floating, and externally as defaulting on sizeable international loans, 3 billion, @ 1/10 of GDP? but no google news alerts regarding Nagorno-Karabakh so seems pretty quiet at the moment Definitely a firecracker as both sides have will and weaponry - one skirmish could develop into an all-out firefight with high  loss of life. Question is could single digits turn into hundreds?
Problem is that violent clashes could easily be up to 99 or more than a hundred.

This is a holding number awaiting word from my peoples in that part of the world, from both the Armenian and the Azerbaijani sides.  They have been more accurate than I on this sort of thing, albeit only marginally.  Stay tuned.

Based on recent history: there was something in the region of slightly over 100 deaths in 2016; and in the region of between 10 and 99 in each year in 2008-15. (Various sources linked from wikipedia entry on NK Conflict; and with some fleshing out from www.europaworld.com).  Recent clashes : April 2016 (four days); December 2015; November 2014 (helicopter shot down); July-August 2014 (11 days); January 2014 (source: www.europaworld.com). Clearly occuring, on average, at least annually. Poltical situation in AM and AZ not markedly changed from the recent past. In Armenia, the nationalist Dashnaqs   (who might be expected to take a harder line than the majoritarian Republicans, who themselves have close links with NK)  have been in governing coalition since early 2016. Azerbaijan leadership has remained, in many regards, subsequently unchanged for years. The president is given to ranting fairly frequently (including on Twitter - English version https://twitter.com/presidentaz ) aggressively about the evils of "Armenian aggression" , and nationalism (and the rewriting of history with regards to anything that pertains to Armenia or Armenians) is a fervent obsesssion. External political situation. The conflict has been "managed" above all by the Minsk Group of the OSCE (co-chairs: USA, France, Russia).   However - it may not be a priority of the current US Administration, while in practice in recent years Russia has taken a greater leadership stance, while selling weapons to both parties.  In theory Russia might be expected to be a closer ally of Armenia, but, as with other networks on relationships in the Caucasus - never mind the greater Middle East - it's complicated.  Could Macron (as the new president of a country that has a non-negligiable Armenian diaspora) push for a de-escalation of tensions between AM and AZ? It's not impossible, but also clearly not uppermost on his in-tray. Foreseeable factors that might promote escalation? None immediately obvious. Next elections in Armenia (which tend to be at least semi-competitive) aren't due until 2022 (although there is the potential for tensions relating to changes in the constitutional balance of powers).  Next elections in Azerbaijan, for the president (the outcome of which is pretty much determined in advance), are due in October 2018, a bit beyond the time span under consideration here. Measures by the de facto Karabakh authorities could also be a trigger. So, stagnation and continuation of existing levels of tension/conflict might be the most probable outcome,unless some major escalation occurs. There could be numerous triggers for this (even tied into the greater Russia-Turkey relations).  But unless there is some broader conflict in the region (not impossible) it seems improbable that there will be a substantial escalation beyond the levels of that which occured in 2016.

This one is for the truly foolhardy, so here I go... For the moment, registering my interest, initial research points, recent developments... Last three days full of mortar fire from both sides and likely to report deaths in the next few days... https://www.azernews.az/karabakh/114918.html But international agenda complex, world not paying attention, changes in the balance of power have altered micro and macro calculations, recent ISDP conference hits the mark on many themes and shows impotence of European/Nato/Russian policy:
http://isdp.eu/news/summary-forum-armenian-azerbaijani-conflict/? And then, the geeky economic, geographic, geopolitical, local aspects of the conflict, in addition to Russia playing two hybrid sides in all its paradoxes...  Economic impact of the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict
